Most would argue that the differences between Robert Diggs and Bobby Digital are essentially nil beyond the latter wearing a paper-plate mask while in character. Not exactly-- the story told by RZA in the Wu-Tang Manual has one major advantage over the narrative sorta-established by his alter ego over the past decade (!) in that it actually has something of a point to it. Namely
column2: that any time the Wu has     been caught slippin'
column3:
it's because everyone else failed to give RZA the benefit of the doubt.

And while it's easy for RZA to claim ownership of 20/20 foresight while trying to do the unprecedented
column4: micromanaging the careers of     eight budding superstars
column5: it wasn't until winter of last year where his artistic leadership underwent real scrutiny. While a Wu-Tang project in name
column6: 8 Diagrams was ultimately considered RZA's baby
column7: as the rest of the Clan (most notably Raekwon and Ghostface Killah) wiped     their hands of it upon release
column8:
slamming the Abbot as a control freak ""hip-hop hippie"" that went behind everyone's back to completely change the character of the record-- a sentiment that gained even more traction after the subsequent drop of Ghost's excellent but cruise-controlled Big Doe Rehab.

But the divisiveness was more talked about than practiced-- both records had nearly equal fortunes commercially (none) and critically (almost rote praise). Still
column9: it's     easy to see how RZA could piggyback on this situation and garner so much     goodwill leading up to his latest solo LP.  First off
column10: he didn't come     out of that fiasco looking as petty as Ghost and Rae do when they bitch to the     media
column11: and while 8 Diagrams wasn't the maverick work of genius some tried to pawn it off as
column12: his sonics did enough     to temporarily deflect the fact that half the Clan sounded frighteningly     washed-up.  More to the point
column13: Bobby     Digital is actually a more trustworthy brand name as far as solo albums go--     his first two bows are uneven
column14: but unhinged semi-classics     amongst the Wu faithful
column15: while Birth of a Prince (released as RZA) contained tracks like ""We Pop"" and ""Fast Cars"" that have few peers in his discography in terms of sheer awfulness.

column1: Yet despite being erudite and lucid in his recent outside pursuits
column2: Digi Snacks finds RZA unable to convey what he really believes
column3: stumbling through mealy-mouthed lyrical and musical ideas before passing the baton to a more engaged but exponentially less interesting subordinate. He's actually become easier to parse-- far less of the ""prominent dominant Islamic Asiatic black Hebrew"" stuff; unfortunately he's a lot harder to understand. Here he's working with about three mismatched cadences at once on ""Booby Trap""
column4: as a     grown man going by the name of Dexter Wiggles shouts
column5: ""Zap! It's a booby     trap/ Would you like a digi or a Scooby snack?""      Even as someone who thought that ""ears of corn/ And heads of lettuce"" ran     on some engine of internal logic
column6: Digi Snacks is unknowable
column7: switching from boilerplate social uplift (""I said
column8: 'damn that's poverty'/ He said
column9: 'that really bothers me'"") to Gods and Earths     pillow talk to Wu mythologizing to standard-issue gun talk
column10: all of it bound together by god knows what-- maybe a weird admiration of Jay-Z's The Black Album?

column1: It's as good of a guess as any
column2: considering RZA bites the     ""Dirt Off Your Shoulder"" flow wholesale on ""No Regrets""
column3: and slaps it on a Maths & English leftover starved of air and funds. But I guess we shouldn't go any further before discussing ""Straight Up the Block""
column4: a collaboration with David Banner that makes more     sense than it first seems-- after all
column5: both have an aversion to meter and a penchant for dubious political conspiracies. But this attempt at an international player's anthem manages to be the most egregious misuse of talent outside of the Mets-- Banner salvages the beat from Swizz Beatz' scrapyard and then tunes down RZA's voice to the point where his slow grind French (""Je m'appelle Bobby Digi-tell...mademoiselle"") tumbles out of his mouth like broken Slinkys.

column1: Advance single ""You Can't Stop Me Now"" gave the impression that we might get a more earthbound
column2: introspective RZA
column3: but it's like ""December 4th"" without those silly interludes-- who hasn't heard this story of     his come-up dozens of times?  It doesn't     help that RZA sounds almost completely uninvested. He could just as easily be     reciting from a book
column4: which is technically an improvement over the thudding
column5: bored     verse from Inspectah Deck
column6: who might as well be rattling through the Yellow     Pages. With that you see the ill effects of the estranged Clan
column7: since Deck's bow is the only one from the A-listers on the entirety of Digi Snacks.

column1: After the turbid nightmares of 8 Diagrams
column2: it's no surprise that Digi Snacks is a notably lighter affair
column3: but it just divides RZA's     work between a pop audience that never really wanted him and the hardcore Wu     heads who think ""Tearz"" is as soft as they should ever get.  ""Good Night"" revives the waterbed motion of ""My     Lovin' Is Digi"" better than the eponymous sequel
column4: mostly because it's still     entertaining to hear didactic rhymes about sinking one's ""Titantic"" (sic)     into your Atlantic and the boundless verbal elasticity needed to fit ""Chicago
column5: ""Virgo
column6: and ""convertible"" in the same rhyme pattern.

column1: If anything
column2: Digi Snacks managed to pinpoint where we are in the Wu cycle of life. In 1998
column3: hip-hop was flush with enough cash     to possibly sustain a Bobby Digital movie and now
column4: low-overhead labels like     Koch ratchet down expectations to the point where it can be pursued as the     niche project it always was.  But     ""half-baked"" isn't an improvement over ""raw"" for a guy like RZA
column5: and anyone     who's heard a recent Kool Keith record can tell you that an astounding catalog
column6: reality-defying self-confidence and an otherworldly alias can't restore rapidly dwindling goodwill on its own. Things just ain't the same for quasi-mad scientist/ghetto philosopher/sexual dynamo superheroes.

It can't be easy being Booka Shade. The Sun and the Neon Light makes their third studio album in three years
column2: in addition to one installment of the mix series DJ-Kicks and numerous EPs
column3: including a collaboration with Hot Chip. Thanks in large part to two of those singles
column4: ""Mandarine Girl"" and ""Body Language""
column5: a collaboration with M.A.N.D.Y. that was deemed Ibiza's 2005 ""Track of the Season
column6: they're among the most globally recognized names in an increasingly fractured electronic dance-music scene
column7: and they tour assiduously to support that reputation. The duo's members
column8: Walter Merziger and Arno Kammermeier
column9: also co-direct Get Physical
column10: the label they founded in 2002 along with Thomas Koch (DJ T) and M.A.N.D.Y.'s Patrick Bodmer and Philipp Jung. But it's not just the length of their workweek
column11: nor the fact that their biggest hits are now three years behind them
column12: that must be tiring. It's their ambitions. Despite their roots in club culture
column13: Booka Shade and Get Physical determinedly pursue the home-listening audience as well as the dance floor
column14: at a time when album sales are down and electronic albums are even more of a ""why bother?"" proposition. As much as fans dance at their shows and DJs play their singles
column15: Booka Shade are rare holdouts for grownup electronica
column16: the kind of subtly shaded comfort listening
column17: equally informed by pop and technological play
column18:
that has all but disappeared in this decade.

The Sun and the Neon Light is certainly their most grown-up album yet: there are fewer obvious singles and more brooding
column19: downtempo moments. While Booka Shade have always been known as a software-centric project-- one of the few acts to be sponsored by a software company
column20: their albums bear the imprimatur of Berlin's Native Instruments
column21: makers of soft-synths like Reaktor and amplifier simulators like Guitar Rig-- they move into the world of ""real instruments"" on this disc
column22: a sure sign of a band intent upon a rather conventional kind of musical maturation. ""Outskirts"" features strings courtesy the German Film Orchestra of Babelsberg; gentle acoustic guitar rustles prominently in ""Solo City""; and there's even a scrap of acoustic blues
column23: a sort of tongue-in-cheek genre cameo
column24:
at the center of ""Dusty Boots"".

What's curious
column25: then
column26: is that The Sun and the Neon Light feels less lively than any of their previous work
column27: in both mood and sonics. I've always suspected that Booka Shade's reliance on software synthesizers bears some of the responsibility for a certain airlessness in their sound
column28: but that hasn't always worked against them: On tracks like ""Mandarine Girl"" and ""Body Language""
column30: pulse-wave sounds that give the music its charge
column31: hovering ominously between euphoria and uncertainty
column32: tinged with a whiff of electrical fire. But this album seems somehow even more cloistered; despite the copious amounts of space in the music-- Booka Shade honed their craft composing music for television advertisements
column33: and they clearly know their way around the studio-- nothing ever seems to really breathe
column34: to open up. I don't mean to privilege one kind of electronic sound over another-- championing ""grit"" in electronic music is often a rockist feint towards specious notions of authenticity
column35: and analog synthesizers and drum machines are not necessarily better than their software-based
column36: ""virtual"" counterparts. But too much of this album feels static
column37:
like a hothouse vacuum.

That's too bad
column38: because it works at cross-purposes with the duo's obvious goal for this record: With four vocal tracks at its core
column39: it's clearly their attempt at pop crossover. Given their reputation for crowd-pleasing
column40: you'd expect them to do it better. ""Pop"" needn't mean Kylie
column42: and it certainly doesn't here: Booka Shade take their cues from Depeche Mode
column43: from chord changes to sound design
column44: from the vocal stylings to the familiar second-person delivery. The vocal melody of ""Control Me"" is a dead ringer for Depeche Mode's ""World in My Eyes""
column45: while the shuffling ""Psychameleon"" is as indebted to ""Personal Jesus"" as it is to Kompakt's glam-derived Schaffel stomp. The songs aren't bad
column46: but they hardly feel essential; something about their neatly resolving chord changes and their careful balance between controlled noise and mellifluous tastefulness seems self-canceling. They dissolve as soon as they're finished. (The lone exception is the quietly overwrought ""Sweet Lies""
column48:
it dissipates just as quickly.)

Two singles
column50: preceded the album in various club mixes
column51: and it's no coincidence that they're the strongest things here. Booka Shade
column53: remain crackerjack composers for the dance floor. ""Charlotte"" expertly juggles a fat
column54: goofy bassline with oodles of squelchy counterpoint lines that spin into a dizzying array of brighter-than-life overtones. (More malleable than all but the most sophisticated of their hardware counterparts
column55: software synthesizers are particularly good at that kind of spine-tingling morphology
column56: and Booka Shade know how to wring every last drop of excitement out of a modulating filter.) I have no idea what they're singing through their vocoders
column57: but here the human element does help to warm up the song; pop and rave in equal measure
column58:
the song's a worthy homage to Madchester's madcap spirit.

""Karma Car"" is even better. No matter that it essentially recycles every trick in the Booka Shade playbook-- or maybe precisely for that reason-- it's one of their best tracks yet. Bleepy contrapuntal phrases
column59: clever chord changes that pivot like universal joints
column60: shivering bass-and-treble harmonies that glide in unison up and down the scale-- they're all here
column62: and a baritone chorus that's genuinely hummable. It's tracks like this that keep me interested in the group. But the ability to score hits doesn't equal the capacity for essential longplayers. Ultimately
column63: The Sun and the Neon Light is an unwittingly perfect title for the album
column64: and not only because it conjures the alternating senses of brooding and yearning that their music aims for. What the title describes is just as ineffable as their sound: you can see it coming down
column65:
but somehow it fails to leave any tangible impression.

The concept that guides Endless Boogie is a relatively simple one: Take the moment at which any good blues-rock jam crests-- the four bars of transcendent face-scrunching and pull-off-laden glory-- then extend that moment onward into oblivion. Focus Level-- the New York City based quartet's first widely available release-- is a choogling zen-prayer
column2: a long-winded invocation to the spirits of Canned Heat
column3: Coloured Balls
column4: and all those who saw the majesty in a pentatonic guitar solo that extended beyond the seven-minute mark. And at 79-minutes long
column5: Focus Level comes about as close to eternity as a compact disc will allow. And that's kind of hard to take in one sitting.

column1: Formed in New York in 1997 by selected Matador Records employees and a professional record collector
column2: Endless Boogie practiced for nearly four years before playing their first show-- an opening slot for Stephen Malkmus in 2001. Since then
column3: the band has done small-scale tours with Dungen and the chameleonic Finnish metal group Circle (who are also their No Quarter label mates) as well performing sporadically in their hometown. They've released two limited press 12"" records-- Endless Boogie I and II-- which have at this point vanished forever into the collector scum ether. A hobby band for aging music nerds
column4: Endless Boogie is dangerously low on careerist aspirations. They won't even play a show unless somebody invites them to.

column1: For the most part
column2: the music on Focus Level can largely be described with the language one might use for a barbecue chicken recipe-- hooks are slow simmered and gooey
column3: leads are greasy
column4: and the skin is slightly charred. Over the course of 10 minutes
column5: songs like ""The Manly Vibe"" and ""Executive Focus"" work the unexplored (and unexpected) ground between Neu! and Black Oak Arkansas-- carrying hypnotic grooves into tongue-wagging bar-rock abandon with the dueling dollar-bin solos of guitarists Paul Major and Jesper Eklow. Major also enhances the swampy vibe with a stew of bridge troll grunts and growls. ""Tell me why that is/ The paper boy don't come no more
column6: he ponders on ""Bad River""
column7: fully capturing the low growl of Captain Beefheart-- and also Dr. Teeth. But the lyrics are just as soon said as forgotten as the band departs on a laid back stroll toward the next guitar solo. Focus Level is rock minimalism at its most casual-- austere repetition and art noise that's good for both the bong-water soaked psych-cognoscenti and the chili cook-off.

column1: But if you've seen enough Coors Light commercials
column2: there's a good chance that a large portion of Focus Level will slide beneath your threshold of sensory perception. It's hard to think of a genre of music more ubiquitous than the electric blues
column3: and after hearing more than an hour of Endless Boogie's mellow chugging the music starts to slide
column4: er
column5: out of focus
column6: becoming a dank and yellow aural wallpaper. Their earlier limited press records each served up one monolithic sidelong jam
column7: and then two snack-size portions-- which is closer to the right dose. Given the band's MO-- you know
column8: endlessness-- it's easy to understand how Endless Boogie couldn't pass up the chance to release a double album. The four-sided record is the hallmark of classic-rock over-indulgence
column9:
and the extension of that indulgence is Endless Boogie's whole show. But it can be a hard show to sit through.

Eliot Lipp released his first album via Prefuse 73's Eastern DeVelopments label

column3: obscurantist electro
column4: his own smooth version seemed especially accessible. To my mind

column6: but Lipp's indelibly outsized themes sear themselves into your brain. He's an unabashed crafter of bangers
column7:
with none of the stereotypical indie producer's crippling fear of transparency.

Lipp's as dependable as ever on The Outside

The Outside could have easily comprised a continuous double-disc with 2006's Tacoma Mockingbird

column11:

Lipp's music is catchy because it's repetitive
column12: establishing an infectious melodic theme and grinding on it for three to five minutes. But it's engaging because it behaves unpredictably within this repetition: Lipp vamps on his themes through fugal variations and diverse FX sweeps. In the cosmopolitan jungle of the title track
column13: he smears his robo-funk theme with acid-squelches and chokes it with sundry gargle effects so it whizzes around like a punctured helium balloon over the pimp-strutting low end. The mellower ""Opening Ceremony"" flips the script: here
column14: it's the low end that distends and mutates
column15: while the hovering synth clouds and pinging melody remain relatively constant
column16: beyond the judicious introduction of some tooth-grinding ring modulator effects.

column1: Lipp also keeps things lively by occasionally expanding his palette beyond toxic-sunrise Korg tones. ""The Area"" slips needling funk guitar and splashes of piano into its stylized neon squiggles
column2: and ""7 Mile Tunnel"" hurls a delicately sliced voice amid the bumper-car synths. And his tonal range is admirable-- he can go mystical
column3: as on ""Beyond the City""
column4: which deploys trills of revelation (similar to those on Four Tet's recent ""Ribbons') to terrific effect; he can go svelte and simmering
column5: as on ""The Meaning""
column6: whose ground-hugging synths lick and glimmer like small flames. He can flip a bassline so clipped and compressed that it sounds alien
column7:
or a bassline so rich and organic it sounds like someone humming. And he can do it all while feeding us exactly the unpretentious heaters we've come to expect from him.

Ever since Brian Eno aligned his epochal album Discreet Music with Erik Satie's call for music that could ""mingle with the sound of knives and forks at dinner
column2: ambient music hasn't worried much about change. Eno's rhetorical sally dates back to 1975
column3: and the story since... well
column4: it's not much of a story in and of itself. What has been a story
column5: as the music has bedded down with softness and nuance
column6:
is how the ""ambient"" enterprise has come to color everything else around it. 

Setting aside their considerable beauty
column7: the ambient tracks on Muting the Noise owe part of their impact to how they fit in with the rest of what's going on in electronic dance music. Such is the fate of any ambient album now
column8: it would seem-- especially when the album is compiled by a dance label in Berlin. That's the home of Innervisions
column9: the label run by house heads Dixon and Âme
column10: and the imprint's stable of producers represents their milieu as more than just a cluster of ambient devotees. What makes ambient tracks by Âme and Henrik Schwarz compelling
column11: then
column12: is not just their amorphous atmospheres
column13:
but also the ways those atmospheres evoke the kinds of atmospheres that both producers rub down in their more rhythmically antic brands of now-sound house.

It would be a mistake to undervalue their considerable beauty
column14: though. If some ambient music is made to be taken for granted
column15: then Âme doesn't help the cause with ""Doldrums""
column16: a gorgeous rush of synth cycles that phase in and out over just the barest hissy suggestion of a beat. Schwarz does it better with ""Arthur""
column17: an intricate piece dotted with a florid piano theme reiterated in different ways and metallic percussion that plays less in measures of rhythmic beats than in timbres of pure sound.

column1: Rhythm doesn't figure strongly on Muting the Noise
column2: aside from the sense of momentum gathered in cycles and loops. A few tracks
column3: Karma's and Tokyo Black Star's especially
column4: fall into that propulsively loping realm of ambient scored by Tangerine Dream in Risky Business. (There's many a fantasy of sensuous train travel to be entertained here.) A couple of others skew as noisy in comparison: I:Cube's ""Nuées Ardentes"" hints at ravy sounds while crackling under with dub
column5: while Stefan Goldmann's ""Life After Death"" plays like a moody piece of musique concrète-- all ghostly reed squeaks and test-tones mixed into a disembodied spell.

column1: Nothing on Muting the Noise stands to redirect what's thought about ambient music as a project or as an addendum to other sounds
column2: but all of it is measured and ambitious in its way. The only curious standout is the outro by Klaus Schulze. With his stints in Tangerine Dream and Ash Ra Tempel and a sizeable solo career
column3: Schulze is a legend
column4: yes
column5:
and his ""Invisible Musik"" covers lots of ground-- but an incongruous running time of 18:08 makes it hard not to at least wonder what happens when ambient steps out beyond its modest means.

If you're a fan of classic music from the African continent
column2: you're living in rich times. Interest in the music outside of the communities it was made in is at an all-time high
column3: and there is a new crop of intrepid reissue labels willing to put in enormous amounts of time and energy to bring this music to a whole new set of waiting ears. These are not the fly-by-night exploito outfits of old-- Popular African Music
column4: Sound Way
column5: Analog Africa
column6: the newly resurrected Strut
column7: and Graeme Counsel's recent series of African music projects on Stern's/Syllart do it the right way
column8: tracking down the original masters when available
column9: finding the artists
column10: and making sure they get paid.

column1: Analog Africa's Samy Ben Redjeb already had loads of cred for the way he handled his two previous releases
column2: which featured Zimbabwe's Hallelujah Chicken Run Band and Green Arrows
column3: respectively. He traveled to Zimbabwe and spent time with the creators
column4: digging deep into their stories and emerging with great-sounding
column5: informative compilations that thoroughly introduced the listener to both the music and the musicians. African Scream Contest moves a few thousand miles northwest to Benin and Togo
column6: two chimney-shaped former French colonies (Togo was a German colony until WWI) squeezed between West Africa's Anglophone giants
column7: Ghana and Nigeria.

column1: These are small countries
column2: usually overshadowed by their neighbors in international affairs but nonetheless culturally and musically rich
column3: and both have experienced the numbingly common ailments of former European colonies to varying degrees. Most of Francophone Africa fell heavily under the sway of Congolese rumba in the 1960s and 70s
column4: or developed heavily Cubanized forms of their own-- Senegal
column5: Guinea
column6: and Mali in particular developed their own sounds parallel to rumba. Benin and Togo were certainly not exempt from rumba's charms
column7: but they were also caught in the highlife crossfire between Ghana and Nigeria
column8: and the funk and soul sounds imported in massive quantities to those countries in the 60s and 70s inevitably found their way across the borders.

column1: There's even a case to be made that Afrobeat developed just as much in Cotonou
column2: Benin
column3: as it did in Lagos
column4: Nigeria. Ignace de Souza & His Melody Aces were pulling in rock elements as early as 1962
column5: and there's plenty of funk in his work with the Black Santiagos-- if you can find a copy
column6: Original Music's long out-of-print Ignace de Souza compilation
column7: <em>the Great Unknowns
column8: Vol. 1
column9: is wall-to-wall brilliant. Benin had an amazing surfeit of excellent bands by the early 70s
column10: and Redjeb tracked down many members
column11: a touch-and-go process he describes vividly in the liners
column12: which function as both educational piece and travelogue.

column1: The kings of the Cotonou scene were Orchestre Poly-Rythmo (there are innumerable variations on their name; the most complete is Tout Puissant Orchestre Poly-Rythmo de Cotonou Dahomey). Though Redjeb makes an admirable attempt to offer as much variety as possible
column2: Poly-Rythmo still shows up three times
column3: once on its own and twice as a backing band. The band recorded in all kinds of styles-- check Popular African Music's Reminiscin' in Tempo disc for their highlife sound
column4: and Sound Way's Kings of Benin Urban Groove for their funk side-- but these three all feature a particularly wicked high-speed groove that they were the first to perfect. Their ""Gbeti Madjro"" is stunningly funky
column5: with a few head-spinning passages where the band strips back to just guitar
column6: bass and drums as if to say ""even at our most skeletal
column7: we are twice as powerful as anyone else.""

column1: The quality of the recordings is excellent
column2: and the remastering brings out the depth in each one
column3: but the character of the sound is about as raw funk gets. Togo's Roger Damawuzan (sometimes spelled Damahouzon) has all the screaming charisma of early-70s James Brown
column4: and his ""Wait for Me"" balances his gruff vocal with a cool
column5: mellow guitar riff and burbling bass. The horns and guitar sound utterly Memphis
column6: but the cracking drums are all West Africa. His countrymen
column7: Napo de Mi Amor et Ses Black Devil's
column8: turn in a burning
column9: organ-led Afrobeat tune that recalls the style of some of their Ghanaian colleagues.

column1: Back in Benin
column2: Orchestre Super Jheevs des Paillotes come closest to matching Poly-Rythmo's breakneck Afrofunk groove on the amazing ""Ye Nan Lon An""
column3: which swivels around an Afrobeat backbeat with a breathtaking guitar part that earns pride of place ahead of the vocals in the mix and makes that upside-down engineering decision sound completely logical. It's counterintuitive moves like this that make African funk such a constant joy to discover
column4: and there are plenty more on this disc. But beyond that
column5: there's just a uniqueness to these musicians' take on funk and Afrobeat that's magnetic. Dig the garage rock organ flipping out over the funk beat of El Rego et Ses Commandos' ""Se Na Min"". Try not to dance to Picoby Band d'Abomey's outrageously raw and rhythmic ""Mi Ma Kpe Dji"". If you're into funky African music you won't be able to resist them.

column1: African Scream Contest easily joins the ranks of the most essential African funk compilations
column2: partly by covering ground no one else has walked on
column3: but mostly just for relentlessly kicking ass for over an hour. This is some of the best funk ever recorded anywhere
column4: and it ranges from quick blasts of hyperspeed groove like Le Super Borgou de Parakou's ""Congolaise Benin Ye"" to the ruminative Fela-style Afrobeat of Vincent Ahehehinnou and Les Volcans' spicy Afro-Cuban workout. Whether you've been hunting down El Rego 45s on eBay for years or just heard and loved your first Fela reissue
column5: this disc is emphatically for you.

column8: water

column1: The best example comes in the middle of The Siren's Wave
column2: during two 10-minute tracks that hit the poles of Nalle's sound. ""Voi Ruusuni (O Rose)"" is an elongated tone-poem with some hypnotic elements
column3: especially Hanna Tuulikki's Yoko Ono-like wail. But mostly the track wanders with no clear destination
column4: its sonic range narrow and its energy level unchanging. By contrast

column6: unrestricted by set patterns

column1: Even when Nalle meanders
column2: you can hear strands of many influences in their loose concoctions

The current decline of the music industry is of course not so much a catastrophic collapse as a simple market correction: a delayed downturn that should've actually begun in the early 1980s
column2: before major labels cajoled consumers into replacing their vinyl collections with shiny CD replications-- thereby artificially padding their bottom lines well into the 90s. But now that record companies have lost control of the means of production
column3: it's funny to see the indie-rock industry resorting to the same behaviour: Making people buy the same albums over and over again
column4: lavishing the reissue treatment not just onto era-defining classics (e.g.
column5: Pavement's Slanted and Enchanted: Luxe and Deluxe set)
column6: but also on albums that were simply very good. Just this spring alone we're being treated to 15th-anniversary editions of Liz Phair's Exile in Guyville
column7: the Lemonheads' It's a Shame About Ray
column8: and Sebadoh's Bubble and Scrape-- albums that were certainly much admired and analyzed in their 1993 inception
column9: but which in 2008
column10: don't really resonate far beyond nostalgic completists.

column1: By that yardstick
column2: Scottish post-rock perennials Mogwai are jumping the gun somewhat
column3: reissuing their debut full-length album
column4: Young Team
column5: in an expanded double-disc edition barely a decade after it first appeared
column6: and given that they've released a steady stream of mildly variable albums since then
column7: it's not as if we've had much of a chance to miss them. But in this particular case
column8: the reissue serves more of a practical than a canonical function-- the label that released Young Team in the U.S. in 1997
column9: Jetset
column10: went kaput several years ago
column11: making what is still the band's most cohesive and consistently bracing album the hardest to find on these shores. But the timing is all the more appropriate given that Mogwai's most recent release
column12: 2006's Mr. Beast
column13: was their most perfunctory set of quiet/LOUD instru-metal to date
column14: so it's an opportune time to revisit the album that made us care in the first place. And the fact that Young Team's influence can still be felt across the international indie-sphere-- not just in kindred art-rock spirits like Sigur Rós and Explosions in the Sky
column15: but also avant-metal outfits like Boris and Pelican-- means the album exists today as something more vibrant than a museum piece.

column1: For a mostly instrumental band
column2: Mogwai have developed a reputation in the media for being big mouths who take no small delight in slagging other bands (hey guys
column3: how about a 10th-anniversary reissue of those ""blur: are shite"" t-shirts?) and praising themselves. However
column4: the spoken-word intro-- a friend reading out a gushing student-paper review of an early Mogwai performance-- that ushers in the slow-burn rapture of Young Team's ""Yes! I Am Long Way From Home"" feels less like a cheeky self-aggrandizing device than a rejection of the hollow Britpop hyperbole that was endemic to the era. But if Mogwai were determined to distance themselves from prevailing retro-rock fashions
column5: Young Team evinced a nostalgic streak of its own
column6: particularly for the pre-Britpop moment of 1988-91
column7: when indie rock bands both American (Slint
column8: Mercury Rev) and British (My Bloody Valentine
column9: Bark Psychosis) were obliterating the parameters of rock music (and the VU meters that quantify them)
column10: before those groups either dissolved or turned more classic rock. So in a sense
column11: Young Team was tending to unfinished business
column12: bridging the continuum the connects shoegaze psychedelia to the anti-pop aesthetic and rhythmic thrust of the then-emergent post-rock.

column1: But
column2: of course
column3: what distinguished Mogwai from the multitude of all-instrumental outfits jockeying for a Thrill Jockey deal was that their post-rock actually rocked. And to this day
column4: nothing in their catalogue attests to this fact more than Young Team's startling second track
column5: ""Like Herod"". Even when you heard it the first time
column6: you knew the song's silently stalking momentum-- guided by Dominic Aitchison's deceptively melodic bassline-- would trigger an eruption of heavy-metal thunder that sounded like Slint soundtracking the shower scene in Psycho. But the tension lies not in question of whether the bomb is going to drop
column7: but when
column8: and this re-mastered reissue does a superb job of prolonging that feeling of impending doom-- during the song's second quiet stretch
column9: you can hear Stuart Braithwaite and John Cummings' fretboard taps panning back and forth in the mix
column10: like an unseen predator taunting you from some unseen location in the shadows before going in for a particularly savage kill. And after 11 years
column11: I'm still never quite prepared for it.

column1: At 11 minutes
column2: ""Like Herod"" is actually only Young Team's second longest song; that honour belongs to 16-minute closer ""Mogwai Fear Satan"". Rather than resorting to sudden dynamic shifts
column3: Young Team's colossal closer masterfully layers sheets of distortion
column4: percussion and flute swirls over a repeated
column5: ascending three-chord progression that-- despite the cacophony swarming around it-- projects a remarkable sense of calm. These two titanic tracks-- still staples of the band's live set-- have traditionally overshadowed the rest of Young Team's tracklist; listening to the album in its entirety today
column6: what strikes you most is not so much Mogwai's brute force
column7: but that these erstwhile piss-takers are capable of moments of great beauty and sensitivity: On the glockenspiel-gilded ballad ""Tracy""
column8: random phone conversations are threaded into the mix
column9: casting the mundane chit-chat in a overwhelmingly melancholic light
column10: rendering the track as a requiem for someone who's no longer with us; on ""R U Still In 2 It""-- Young Team's lone vocal track-- guest singer Aidan Moffatt of Arab Strap duets with Braithwaite on a devastating anti-love song that vividly captures a dead-end relationship being strung along by declarations of non-commital commitment.

column1: Given how prolific Mogwai were in their formative years
column2: much of what would normally be considered for anniversary-edition extras was already released 10 years ago
column3: in the form of the Ten Rapid singles collection
column4: the 4 Satin and No Education = No Future (Fuck the Curfew) EPs and the Kicking a Dead Pig remix collection. So all that this reissue's second ""Appendix"" disc can offer is one unreleased track (the suitably mournful ""Young Face Gone Wrong"")
column5: a couple of compilation rarities
column6: and a hearty serving of Young Team concert/radio-session recordings. The band's faithful version of Spacemen 3's ""Honey"" (taken from a 1998 tribute album) provides insight into Mogwai's more melodic influences
column7: and seven-inch obscurity ""I Can't Remember"" finds the band toying around with a DJ Shadow-esque drum loop
column8: but the live tracks mostly stick to the script-- the one revelation being that
column9: in concert
column10: Mogwai seem to be in more of a hurry to plow through ""Like Herod"" and ""Mogwai Fear Satan""
column11: lopping several minutes off of each. Still
column12:
the version of ""Satan"" that closes this collection-- taken from Chemikal Underground's fifth anniversary party in 2000-- does add one sound effect that the original Young Team version merely implied: the sound of ecstatic applause confirming minds well blown.

column2: when not being dismissed outright

column7: this tendency has reduced France's historical context. Magma is often filed away from its country in the auspices of the krautrock section
column8: Parisian synth-punk groups like Metal Urbain are often viewed as a dark answer to-- you guessed it-- punk
column9: and progressive and electronic composers like Richard Pinhas languish in the shadows of Manuel Göttsching
column10: Klaus Schulze
column11: and Conrad Schnitzler. But Pinhas
column12: whose Single Collection 1972-1980 has recently been issued by Japan's Captain Trip label
column13: has left just as long a legacy as any of his German contemporaries. This CD compiles a number of Pinhas's early 7"" singles
column14: all released before the de facto beginning of his solo career
column15: the 1980 masterpiece Iceland.

column1: Even at his best
column2: Pinhas also isn't above being directly influenced by his forebears. Alongside his solo work
column3: the disc also chronicles Pinhas's work in the witty blues-based psych-rock outfit Schizo
column4: as well as his Berlin School-influenced sequencer work with Heldon and his further experimentations in that scene as THX. Pinhas exhibited a fluidity that moved in the flowing undercurrent of technology in the mid-1970s
column5: adopting the Moog and later sequencer sounds of his contemporaries with a decidedly direct approach to melody. These singles show Pinhas never shying away from synthesized or guitar-based leads at the outset
column6: spurning the patient

column8: an eight-minute Heldon tune that owes a lot to Tangerine Dream's Rubycon and Phaedra
column9: wastes little time in developing a bass synthesizer progression
column10: and then an oblique distorted guitar lead.

column4: a la Robert Fripp. Unfortunately

column6: piano-pounded  freak-out ""Imitation of the Sky"" suggests he’s already fantasizing about a crossover theatrical adaptation. But it'll be one narrative logic takes a back seat to spectacle: in just four minutes

column5: Josef K burned bright but briefly

column7: Haig has had a mostly overlooked solo career-- much of it spent shifting his attention from strummy guitars to slick dance pop. But frustrated that his commercial aspirations never quite bore fruit
column8: Haig more or less fell from view
column9: his erratic back catalog in and out of print save for Josef K's brilliant output.

column1: Don't call it a comeback
column2: but
column3: well
column4: the Paul Haig some know and love has returned. A recent Scottish show marked Haig's first live set in almost 20 years
column5: and by all accounts the music leaned heavy on the guitar. Not that Go Out Tonight is any less of a dance record than some of its predecessors

column3: buoyed by acoustic guitar and some old school programming or the more propulsive rave-ups ""Shut Down"" and ""Data Retro"".

column1: Then again
column2: it's hard to tell if the likes of ""Hippy Dippy Pharmaceutically Trippy"" is terrible or tolerable
column3: and ""Fantasize"" and ""Acidic Snowdrop"" both feel at least a couple of decades of dance music off. Indeed
column4: as pop goes
column5: Go Out Tonight teeters on the edge of piffle
column6: and rarely comes close to brilliant. Still
column7: you can't begrudge Haig's belated if ultimately half-hearted attempts to seize the spotlights. Maybe he's a star in his own mind

column10:
no doubt spent doggedly looking for the perfect beat.

That images like these could apply to most dark ambient records limits their usefulness
column3: except to say that this album satisfies a fundamental criterion of good abstract music: It lights up the imagination.

column1: More specifically
column2: In Between Words is both calming and unsettling
column3: very familiar and very strange
column4: because Bissonnette is essentially turning the familiar Romantic-era music of the 19th and early-20th centuries inside-out. This isn't Bissonnette's innovation-- titans like Morton Feldman paved the way-- yet the effect is especially pronounced on In Between Words. To test this idea
column5: get your hands on a piece of Romantic music: Something dark and gusty and depressive that trembles exhaustedly on the cusp of Modernism will work best. Jean Sibelius' Symphony No. 4 in A Minor is really rad and perfect to illustrate this point.

column1: Listen to the string parts for awhile. First
column2: you'll notice the soul-wrenching melodies and the stories they tell. Then
column3: you'll hear the quiet
column4: somnolent rumble all around them. This balance of fluent melody and brooding atmosphere is part of why Romantic music was so good at the 360-view-of-human-experience thing: Like the great Russian novels of the same era
column5: it combined rabid conviction with searing doubt. Its melodies told stories of human striving and collective belief
column6: but its disquieting sub-tones hinted at the existential uncertainty at the fringes of these stories
column7: which would come to dominate Modernism.

column1: In Between Words flips the Romantic dichotomy on its head
column2: pulling the sub-tones to the surface and burying the remnants of narrative. ""Provenance"" begins with a desolate expanse of what sounds like stringed resonance with the actual melody edited out
column3: as if someone had stripped away every narrative agent from a Sibelius symphony until only the murky hum at its root remained. When a discernible string melody appears
column4: it's distended
column5: distant
column6: and wracked with electrical interference. Similarly
column7: ""Orffyreus Wheel"" (note the tellingly corrupted mythological reference in the title) finds what sounds like a flanged guitar melody trying to articulate itself through a calm but obliterative gale. ""A Touch of Heartbreak"" sets hollowed-out ghost voices in a blank
column8: seething field
column9: gradually whiting out into hushed static
column10: and ""Tempest"" sounds like a carillon (a shortcut to religious ecstasy in Romantic music) being dragged awkwardly over craggy terrain.

column1: The stories these compositions tell are not about mythology
column2: or heroism
column3: or even misery and ruin. In fact
column4: they're not stories at all. Instead
column5: they're elegies for the grand meta-narratives that guided high Romanticism
column6: which were approached skeptically by Modernism and hostilely  by Postmodernism. Bissonnette is firmly in the latter camp: Right there in the album's deconstruction-redolent title
column7: he lets us know that he's most interested in what's unsaid. Luckily
column8: he's an eloquent un-sayer
column9: and his music is elevated beyond the cerebral by a palpable longing for a time when meaning wasn't regarded such a chimerical
column10: capricious thing.

Human beings have invented hundreds of instruments for themselves
column2: on which to play an incredible range of different musics-- I went through a phase in my music listening where I'd buy an album just because it had weird instruments on it. But as fun as it is to seek out all the different timbres and tonal possibilities on offer
column3: you could spend a pretty satisfying lifetime just listening to all the ways a single instrument can be used a re-employed in different contexts and by different players. Hell
column4: you could probably spend a lifetime just building a thorough understanding of all the ways the piano is used in jazz.

column1: Take a trawl back through the instrument's recorded history in the genre
column2: and you'll find all kinds of approaches-- a knowledgeable listener will never mistake the swirling
column3: busy style of Art Tatum for Thelonious Monk's dissonant
column4: strangely twisting improvisations
column5: for instance. In the jazz world
column6: it's a fight for every musician to carve out his or her own little instrumental niche
column7: to find that thing as a musician that makes them distinct. Some never do
column8: others constantly change in a search for their style
column9: and still others are just born to sound like no one but themselves.

column1: It's not a stretch to put Vijay Iyer in that final category. Iyer has a very unique approach to comping chords
column2: constantly moving back and forth between notes in the chord to create a throbbing background pulse. It's more a sheet of sound than traditional jazz piano. You'll hear it used as an effect frequently in jazz
column3: but it's rare that this textural technique becomes the center of a player's style
column4: and it's made Iyer's playing uniquely suited to crossing the thin lines between jazz and hip-hop to collaborate with indie hip-hop auteur Mike Ladd.

column1: Along with his two headlining collaborations with Ladd
column2: Iyer's helmed or co-helmed a dozen LPs-- he stretches his style in every direction imaginable
column3: and his compositions tend to mix moody textural passages with bursts of odd rhythm
column4: some that even sound like riffs. Modern jazz rarely follows the old ""head/solos/head"" format that typified be-bop
column5: and Iyer uses his compositions as mood pieces
column6: setting them against each other in a bid to change the feeling the record produces from song to song.

column1: He has a versatile band in saxophonist Rudresh Mahanthappa
column2: bassist Stephan Crump
column3: and drummer Marcus Gilmore
column4: who flow right along with him and easily handle the odd meters and start-stops he gives them. The album creeps into being with the nebulous
column5: slowly coalescing ""The Weight of Things"" (it's an open improv credited to the whole group) before exploding into a full-on lurch on ""Macaca Please"". Mahanthappa does some of his most ferocious lead playing on this track
column6: though he outclasses himself later in the album on ""Without Lions""
column7: where his sax line practically sounds like a jazz take on ""Flight of the Bumblebee"".

column1: Tragicomic
column2: true to its title
column3: is an album about balance-- see the way
column4: for example
column5: that Iyer follows the buoyant sunny ""I'm All Smiles"" with the evil
column6: odd-metered stormer ""Machine Days""-- and what rises from nothing at the beginning dissipates again into nothing again with the final track. It's the end note to a satisfying album from a unique pianist who continues to show us what his instrument can do.

Released in 2005 to widespread acclaim
column2: the first volume of Tompkins Square's series Imaginational Anthem stands as a high-water mark of the contemporary American Primitive guitar movement. Since that collection's release
column3: the deluge of fingerpicked guitar records has continued unabated
column4: and Tompkins Square has become the sort of magnet for talented guitarists that John Fahey's legendary Takoma label once was. A second Imaginational Anthem compilation arrived in 2006
column5: and several of the series' alumni-- including James Blackshaw
column6: Jack Rose
column7: Glenn Jones
column8: and José González-- have since each released multiple solo albums across a variety of labels. At the same time there has also arrived a bounty of unearthed 1960s-era folk guitar albums
column9: including Tompkins Square's own reissues of seminal works by Robbie Basho and Harry Taussig.

column1: The American Primitive market therefore is as flooded as it has ever been
column2: and even the most diehard guitar aficionados can afford to be pretty goddamn choosy. So due to the timing of its arrival-- and thanks in no small part to Tompkins Square's own success at making so much top-flight guitar music available-- the new Imaginational Anthem Vol. 3 bravely risks redundancy as it returns once again to the seemingly inexhaustible folk-guitar wellspring.

column3: handcrafted touch

column6: and Robbie Basho

column9: Cian Nugent (Ireland)

column11: as well as players from virtually every corner of America. Despite this globetrotting

The Crystal Stilts are moody-sounding fuckers who make fabulous stripped-down garage-pop. Their mix-and-match post-punk ditties manage to sound both affected and effective at the same time; they're weirdly life-affirming and very fun. You want to dance when you hear them-- dance with a furrowed brow
column4: maybe
column5: but move around nonetheless. Singer Brad Hargett is from Brooklyn by way of Florida but sounds like he's from Manchester by way of Slough. The main thing I wonder when I listen to Crystal Stilts is why is it so hard to make exceptional garage-pop like this? I mean
column6: how hard can it be to plonk out a little la-la-loo-lee number on your $80 Sears guitar or your beat-up Casio and then record the thing in the bathroom in one take? It's been stated in ways both eloquent (David Fair's brilliant and oft-quoted manifesto ""How to Play Guitar"") and cheesy as heck (Bono's ""three chords and the truth"" which he lifted from Harland Howard re: Hank Williams)
column7: but should it not by definition be simple to do this?

column1: Of course it is not. Rock'n'roll is theft-- all the great ideas have been recycled a thousand one times already. So to hit upon a winning combination of old and new gets harder than coming up with a band name that doesn't return hundreds of hits when you plug it into the old Google. (I have to say that I wish another band had already called themselves Crystal Stilts already
column2: as the name outright blows-- plus what's with the mini-plague of Crystal bands?) Self-limiting is the key to great garage-pop: By keeping it stripped-down on purpose-- whether you're the Saints ca. 1975 or Beat Happening ca. their whole career-- you unleash something greater than yourself. This is the Oulipian ideal
column3: that one can free the subconscious by making oneself a drone to either the obvious or to seemingly haphazard rules. It's also partly why La Monte Young is punk as fuck-- but you know that already.

column1: Crystal Stilts do not sound like the Saints or Beat Happening or La Monte Young. These are weird pop songs you clap your hands along to. They pile a rockabilly riff and nursery school melodies onto a revved-up bass line and sweet surfy 60s organ riff on top of minimalist percussion on the song ""Crystal Stilts"". The amazing ""Crippled Croon"" takes the stand-up drum roll from ""Just Like Honey"" and grafts echoed-up vocals
column2: a reverb-swallowed guitar
column3: and a sub-atomic bass line onto it. And ""Shattered Shine""
column4: with its psychedelic layers of tambourine
column5: guitar
column6: and organ
column7: is a perfect marriage of Ian Curtis-y doom with sunshine-y Shop Assistants-style pop. The Stilts sing in fake Brit-sounding accents
column8: but somehow the dude's droll
column9: goth-y croon never grates; it helps that the band pushes his vocals way low in the mix.

column1: In what little press the band has gotten
column2: they've been compared to New Zealand bands. I feel that a lot of this alleged New Zealand copping has been pasted onto the Stilts because it was Clean drummer/singer Hamish Kilgour who helped to ""discover"" and help the group out. It's worth pointing out that in the 80s themselves
column3: many American acts were greatly influenced by NZ groups. It was the late 80s
column4: of course (and on into the early 90s)
column5: but acts as beloved today as Pavement and Neutral Milk Hotel-- as well as currently obscure acts such as World of Pooh and Wingtip Sloat-- would have sounded a lot different if they hadn't been buying up every Flying Nun record they could get their hands on back in the day. Some folks complain that they cannot understand Brad Hargett's lyrics
column6: but pop lyrics are typically a disappointment. Burying them is actually a winning strategy
column7: and it's a safe bet that this is intentional-- that Crystal Stilts are aesthetes and are doing this because they also like records that sound this way. Either that
column8:
or the Stilts are broke as shit.

There are basically two ways to compile obscure old music: one is to focus on a story
column3: say that of a single performer or a record label
column4: and the other is to do an overview with sensible
column5: if ultimately arbitrary parameters. It's possible to make a satisfying collection using either method
column6: but you have to do it right regardless: When diligent research
column7: good sound and good music collide on the same disc
column8: you have the best of all worlds
column9: and something truly worth owning. Jazzman has made something of an art form out of the latter approach with its recent geographically organized survey of impossibly rare funk. Carolina Funk follows on the fine heels of the label's Midwest
column10: Texas
column11: and Florida Funk overviews
column12: dishing out 22 killer sides from late 1960s and early-to-mid-70s North and South Carolina
column13: accompanied by 22 pages of extensive
column14: tiny-type liners that offer more background than most people will know what to do with.

column1: The compilation covers a broad spectrum: There are hard psychedelic funk sides
column2: funky soul songs
column3: murky basement disco grooves
column4: vocal harmonies
column5: and screaming James Brown disciples
column6: all played at skill levels ranging from confidently professional to charmingly amateur. The biggest name on the tracklisting is Carleen & the Groovers
column7: which illustrates just how lost to time most of these tracks were. There are a couple of things seeing their first commercial release
column8: and there is definitely a collector's penchant for rarity at work in the song choices. There's no distinct sound tying all these songs together-- if anything
column9: the opposite is true. If there's a common thread to be found
column10: it's that the vibrant funk scene of the Carolinas was mostly a hyper-local phenomenon
column11: with very few of the featured musicians ever touring or receiving distribution outside their city much less their state.

column1: The disc opens with the ludicrous spoken-word intro to Primitive's ""Creation of Music""
column2: a dorky
column3: faux-Biblical announcement that God created music
column4: in the manner of His famous ""let there be light"" pronouncement. And then it tears up the dance floor with a nasty rhythm guitar
column5: twisting sax
column6: and a burbling bass line. The skeletal groove pioneered by James Brown is all over these songs
column7: and these bands play it hard
column8: the often roughshod production only serving to highlight the attack of each scratchy guitar chord or well-hit snare. There are two direct homages to Carolina's #1 soul brother (JB was born in South Carolina) in Dynamite Singletary's ""Super Good"" and the Soul Impossibles' ultra-gritty ""Interpretation: Soul Power No. 1""
column9: both of which are essentially modifications of similarly named Brown tracks.

column1: The riches sitting in the bins of Carolina flea markets are apparently plentiful
column2: and some of these songs are just dying to be heard by audiences far larger than their 250-count pressings allowed. Wally Coco's ""Message to Society""
column3: the most disco-fied track on the disc
column4: is a groove monster that pleasingly combines the slick rhythms taking over the dance floors of the late 70s with garage-rock caliber production. That's hardly the craziest groove here
column5: though-that's probably the Soul Drifters' ""Funky Soul Brother""
column6: which opens with a stinging wah guitar riff that
column7: along with ridiculously tight drumming
column8: co-anchors an amazing bass line
column9: gang vocals
column10: and horn lines that embody the adjective ""stabbing."" The horns on Paul Burton's ""So Very Hard to Make It"" are anything but stabbing
column11: their rich orchestration providing a creamy backdrop for Burton's smooth soul croon.

column1: If you're a fan of old-school funk
column2: picking this compilation up is a no-brainer. If you're an old-school funk dilettante
column3: you could still do worse-- this isn't material with limited appeal
column4: even if it had limited impact in its day. The lack of success most of these bands experienced had a lot more to do with simple geography and economics. The various Carolina funk scenes may have been poor for cash or resources
column5: but they were rich with creativity.

column3: descending guitar crashes in over a 4/4 drum machine beat that sounds     like frozen meat being punched

column15: I'll take you to my mom's"").

column1: The record gets a little more frazzled and hedonistic as it goes on. ""Herman Choune"" begins with near-psychedelic organ tones

column1: In Re-Arrange Us

By now
column2: readers are familiar with Julian Cope's 1995 book Krautrocksampler
column3: which helped rekindle appreciation of post-war German psychedelia. Thing is
column4: most of us have never had a chance to read it
column5: as it's looooooong out of print (Amazon's best price as of this writing is $213.10). This mirrors problems with the experimental artists Cope writes about
column6: who often cut small-run releases for regional audiences. Listeners these days can now get re-issued Ash Ra Tempel
column7: but many readers will have to be contented with Cope's recently-released companion piece Japrocksampler

column1: Just as with their German contemporaries
column2: LRD remains shrouded in mystery. Formed in 1967 at Kyoto University and playing shows up until 1996
column3: the group mingled dirge-like rhythms with piercing guitar feedback
column4: which is easy to tell from the live document Eve Night. They incorporated acid-washed takes on sunny San Francisco psych-rock and were always guided by avant-garde Japanese theatre. Their sound played a big part in fellow countrymen Acid Mothers Temple
column5: as well as serving as a template for the likes of Flipper and the Melvins in the States. And Les Rallizes managed to do all this while hardly touching the studio.

column1: Instead
column2: their legend has grown on the back of monolithic performances
column3: deafening volume
column4: and jarring lightshows. Mythically militant
column5: the group was known for distributing Marxist propaganda at junior high schools
column6: and bassist Moriaki Wakabayashi was involved in the hijacking of an airliner by extremist group Sekigun. They were a group of towering guitar riffs
column7: hard psych
column8: inscrutable vocals
column9: and radical ideals that simply blew away the audiences of the post-war Japanese underground. Those who know LRD today most likely heard them via one of their many live records like Eve Night
column10: some legitimate and some bootlegged
column11: and the group's releases remain sought-after collectors' items.

column1: But what's the big deal with these guys? Many of their available releases are the worst of bootleg tripe: badly recorded college campus shows taken from the deck of an amateur sound engineer. But Eve Night is of particular interest because it's cut of a different sort than those back-alley CD-Rs. The set
column2: recorded at a Housei University show in 1983
column3: is a good recording that catches the group on a damn good night. It's easier to hear the dynamic interplay between widely disparate vocals
column4: rhythm
column5: guitar
column6: and bass than
column7: say
column8: Eve Night's concurrently re-issued 1974 companion
column9: Are You Rallizesed? The jams
column10: which sometimes range over twenty minutes in length
column11: tend to initially bear some resemblance to the 1960s California sound covered on the recent Rhino compilation Love Is The Song We Sing: San Francisco Nuggets 1965-1970
column12: which features groups like Quicksilver Messenger Service
column13: the Front Line
column14: and the Dead. But the heavy machinations of Les Rallizes bear more in common with their hard-psych contemporaries Hawkwind.

column1: Eve Night is a wonderful document of the group not only because it's so clear
column2: but because it catches the subtleties of their range
column3: which is sometimes hard to hear in low-quality bootlegs. Singer Takashi Mizutani is never spectacular
column4: and he often seems to be trying to be less than spectacular
column5: but on cuts like their famous dirges ""Enter the Mirror"" and ""The Last One""
column6: he affects the voice of a lonely
column7: wandering spirit in the throes of an existential revelation. As counterpoint
column8: LRD's superbly fuzzy guitar lead is the mark of a group that has transcended the blues
column9: transcended drugs
column10: and after sixteen years
column11: remains in an impressionistic prime.

column1: Ignuitas
column2: the label that issued Eve Night
column3: is similarly enigmatic. They don't have much in the way of PR
column4: and their liner notes are frustratingly minimalist

column8: Larry Levan
column9: Valerie Solanas
column10: King Ludwig II of Bavaria.

column2: oh
column3: you know
column4: fun

column6: humor

column8: it's impossible to hear it and not entertain questions about how they might work within those bounds. By the simple act of listening

column7: weirdly and wonderfully

column2: flirting with interested record labels of varying liquidity
column3: engaging in slapfights with the Dandy Warhols and fistfights with bandmates-- the myth and mystique surrounding the group all but drowned out its songs.  All the while

column5: a tortured outcast inspired by and continuing the work begun by his spiritual forefathers from the 1960s
column6: including one or both of the guys whose names or notorious actions were jacked for use in Newcombe's little beat combo.

column1: With every subsequent release
column2: however
column3: the myth gave way to a less flattering portrait.  Although Newcombe was talented enough to skillfully synthesize all sorts of musical touchstones
column4: the end results were increasingly less inspiring
column5: and his tendency to take decent ideas and beat them into the ground was maddening-- Newcombe never failed to take what could be a perfectly fine three-minute song and turn it into an interminable seven-minute dirge.  Couple those aesthetic shortcomings with Newcombe's  penchant for burning bridges and buying into his own out-of-proportion hype
column6: and it's no wonder that the group quickly became yesterday's news.  Ironically
column7: Brian Jonestown Massacre's most public moment came courtesy of the 2004 documentary Dig!
column8: with the film's unflattering portrayal of Newcombe and the group's overwrought inner turmoil showing exactly why the group would never become as big as Newcombe thought they should be.  Undaunted

column10: releasing records
column11: playing out

column1: Given its title

column3: the album often sounds more like a poorly recorded group of proficient amateurs giving it a go on fourth-hand guitars and some empty paint buckets
column4: with the singer warbling through a pillow for good measure.  The album's lead track (the name of which I'll get to later on) starts with a promising beat
column5: but gets sideswiped not three seconds in by the intrusion of the meandering psychedelic guitar mangling one might stereotypically expect from a group beholden to that forever-romanticized era of free love.  After six minutes of that
column6: there's an electrified version of the same pointless stumble that lasts just as long.  Most of the album offers variations on this sort of unending drone-- ""Who Fucking Pissed in My Well?"" is a non-vocal synth-driven take
column7: ""Just Like Kicking Jesus"" goes the MBV seasick route
column8: ""Who Cares Why"" sends the drone out into orbit

Chicha Libre is an anomaly
column2: a modern American band playing a kind of music that was popular among the working classes of northern Peru in the 1960s and 70s. If the style of music they play were a star
column3: they would be a planet that arrived to orbit it decades after it faded out. It's a phenomenon that's grown in the last ten years: Western bands building their music on an obscure
column4: vaguely familiar blueprint from outside their own culture. There are scores of North American and European Afrobeat bands
column5: and Dengue Fever pattern themselves on Cambodian garage rock. It's cultural imperialism in reverse; these bands embrace the sometimes-unexpected way in which musicians in other countries interpreted our own music and use it as inspiration.

column1: That Chicha Libre's debut album is out on Barbés Records makes sense. It's the label
column2: after all
column3: that last year released the excellent Roots of Chicha compilation
column4: a disc that highlighted the chicha music of Amazonian Peru. Like Tropicália
column5: soukous
column6: and reggae
column7: Chicha was a syncretic pop style
column8: built on the back of the Colombian cumbia
column9: a dance form with roots in West Africa. Chicha musicians used the cumbia's rhythmic foundation
column10: underpinning their songs with congas
column11: shakers
column12: and claves
column13: but replaced the traditional acoustic guitars and accordions with electric guitars
column14: basses
column15: and Farfisa organs. They also grafted on the pentatonic scales of traditional Andean and Amazonian music and incorporated elements of Cuban and American pop
column16: especially surf guitar music.

column1: The result of all this blending was something totally original and distinctive. It became the soundtrack to the sudden urbanization of far inland Peru
column2: as the mid-60s oil boom swept across the country's rugged and vast Loreto region. In cities like Iquitos
column3: which rests on the bank of the Amazon
column4: it was a thrilling new thing to dance to
column5: quite unlike anything available before it. And because surf music itself was syncretic
column6: borrowing melodies and pentatonic scales from Greece and Middle East
column7: it fit right in as an element of the new sound. The name comes from a Latin American equivalent of a microbrew-- chicha is a family of fermented beverages made of widely varied base ingredients in Central and South America. In northern Peru
column8: the word was also uniquely used to describe the transient lifestyle of temporary workers.

column1: Chicha eventually spread all the way to Lima on the coast
column2: but never gained wide notoriety
column3: in part because of its low-class origins. Even most compilations of Peruvian rock music leave it out in favor of garage bands like Los Yorks and Anglicized psych bands like We All Together (both of which are great
column4: nonetheless). Something so powerful had to come back to the surface eventually
column5: though
column6: and now that it has
column7: Chicha Libre is there to breathe some new life into it
column8: taking the sound back to its roots (modern chicha groups tend to sound pretty different from their forebears
column9: using digital synths and drum machines) while adding a few of their own touches.

column1: ¡Sonido Amazonico! takes its title from a stunning psychedelic surf instrumental by Los Mirlos
column2: one of the best and most vital chicha bands. A faithful and great cover of that song leads of the album
column3: immediately grasping the humid vibe that makes old-time chicha so arresting. The psychedelic organ solo is fantastic. The members   don't exactly have Latino names-- Burrows
column4: Camp
column5: Conan
column6: Cudahy
column7: Douglas
column8: and Quigley-- but they do sing in Spanish (quite competently)
column9: and they approach the music with genuine affection but not so much that they're slaves to their influences.

column1: For instance
column2: distortion was exceedingly rare in chicha music
column3: but they employ a modest amount of it on the opening guitar theme of ""Primavera en la Selva""
column4: a brilliant track that borrows melodic themes for the organ and guitar from Vivaldi's ""Four Seasons"" and garage rocks the hell out of them. Nicking classical themes was a favorite habit of chicha bands (Los Destellos' version of ""Für Elise"" is amazing)
column5: and Chicha Libre pick up the thread
column6: cutting a version of a Ravel pavane and closing the album with a slinky surf-cumbia version of Satie's ""Gnosienne No.1"". They also do one of the best versions of Gershon Kingsley's pop standard ""Popcorn"" I've ever heard

column1: Though they are obviously tailoring their talents to fit a specific sonic mold
column2: the efforts of the band members don't sound forced. In fact
column3: they seem to write in the style with a minimum of effort. Perhaps it's simply the fact that a well-constructed melody can be adapted to just about any setting

column1: As much as I'm in love with the record
column2: though
column3: I admit that it is still probably destined for a niche market of listeners who are interested in these sorts of global melting pot sounds-- Spanish lyrics likely won't help it on that front. Not that that's a bad thing
column4: just a marketplace reality. Regardless
column5: ¡Sonido Amazonico! achieves what it sets out to do
column6: which is to pay creative homage to an overlooked genre from a corner of the world few of us will ever see but all of us are invisibly connected to by the weather.

Can an album really be a departure if it's the first thing a group's released in 11 years? It ideally would be for a genre-bound band turned brand name like Portishead: As much as there is to miss about the mid-late 1990s
column2: the time for any trip-hop revival is far into the future
column3: and picking up right where they left off in 1997 would make Portishead some kind of sad cipher coasting on the fumes of an exhausted trend-- something they've always been above. If the voice of Beth Gibbons wasn't so ingrained in the consciousness of a whole generation of indie kids
column4: you could look at Third as a sort of re-debut; it posits that the sound of Portishead can actually exist even after the group excises every possible remnant of trip-hop from it.

column1: As radical reinventions go
column2: Third is surprisingly natural. You can credit Gibbons as the familiarizing factor: She possesses a voice that seems impossible to shackle to just one musical setting
column3: even if it already sounds perfectly at home in brooding downtempo ambience. As the most recognizable component of the group
column4: she has the most established stylistic tendencies-- subtle quivers
column5: an ability to go from hushed to piercing without laboring over the transition
column6: an aching timbre that expresses anxious vulnerability better than nearly any other singer-- and she slips back into them comfortably when she needs to.

column1: But it's also a style that works in more contexts than we've previously heard
column2: something she hinted at with Rustin Man on 2002's folk and jazz-influenced Out of Season
column3: and Third is the culmination of this. Pitted against the jarring mechanical stop-starts of first single ""Machine Gun"" or the chase-scene-paced opener ""Silence""
column4: Gibbons sounds like both a defiant accuser and someone clinging on for dear life. Quieter numbers
column5: like the slow-build electronic ballad ""The Rip"" or the softer moments of the cabaret highwire act ""Hunter""
column6: highlight the fragility in her voice. And since almost every song on Third addresses some sort of emotional or mental helplessness-- typically a deep and profound sense of loss and isolation-- it's almost as though this shift in sonic identity is there to mask the fact that this is an incredibly bleak record lyrically. Gibbons' wounded tone can take commonplace-on-paper sentiments (""I'd like to laugh at what you said but I just can't find a smile""; ""I can't deny what I've become/ I'm just emotionally undone"") and give them a kind of pathos that's almost uncomfortably voyeuristic to listen to.

column1: As for how the music itself has changed
column2: long story short: Third is a psychedelic rock album. It opens with a rhythm that's nearly twice as fast as almost everything else Portishead have done
column3: the percussion on most of the songs is frequently muffled or buried under layers of noise and sometimes just stops short of being non-existent (though it's heavy and propulsive when it does make itself known)
column4: and their keyboards and strings have graduated from relaxed tension into dissonant rumbles and shrieks. There's a brief acoustic folk song (""Deep Water"")
column5: an abrasive and jittery electro-industrial number (""Machine Gun"")
column6: free jazz horns (""Magic Doors"")
column7: analog freakouts from the United States of America-fueled early days of electronic psych (""The Rip"")
column8: and a song that sounds a bit like Clinic's droning
column9: rhythmically dense garage-kraut
column10: except somehow spookier (""We Carry On""). Portishead as you previously knew them are represented
column11: barely
column12: by the last song on the album-- the sleepwalk-paced
column13: David Axelrod-esque ""Threads""-- and even then
column14: its intermittently fuzzed-out tension-and-release dynamic would've made it one of the harshest-sounding songs on Dummy or Portishead.

column1: <span>You could say that this would be unrecognizable as a Portishead album without Gibbons' voice
column2: and you'd be sort of right; guitarist and contributing songwriter Adrian Utley mentioned in a recent New York Times article that one of the rules they set for Third was that they couldn't fall back on any instruments-- or even any trademark sounds-- that they'd used on previous albums. But their style here isn't particularly out of character
column3: comparatively experimental as it is; Utley's guitar still twangs sharply when it's not doing things like interjecting ""Iron Man"" growls in ""Hunter"" or splintering into Syd Barrett-isms at the coda of ""Small""
column4: and the melodic identity that he and Geoff Barrow built on a foundation of minor keys and sinister grandeur still holds sway. In the terms of a group that was frequently lumped in with film composers as much as Bristol axis peers
column5: Portishead's Euro-cool John Barry intrigue has been pushed into the disquieting territory of John Carpenter's compositions and Bernard Herrmann's Alfred Hitchcock scores.

column1: Keep in mind just how out-of-nowhere this all seems: The notion of a new Portishead album had
column2: for many fans
column3: fallen out of the realm of possibility. If Third had come out in 1999 or 2000
column4: maybe writers would be calling it Portishead's answer to Massive Attack's Mezzanine
column5: another third album by trip-hop icons eschewing dinner-conversation music by embracing anxiety and moodiness. Released today
column6: it instead feels like a staggering transformation and a return to form that was     never lost
column7: an ideal adaptation by a group that many people didn't know they needed to hear again.
