How do you finish a puzzle when the guy in the picture is holding the last piece? This is the question Numero Group's Rob Sevier and Ken Shipley ask in their liner notes for Don't Stop: Recording Tap. The question is rhetorical
column2: of course
column3: a way of explaining how difficult it was to assemble this compilation of a New York record label that was so obscure that it barely even released records and most of the people involved who can be located don't even want to talk about it. The label's very founder
column4: Jeremiah Yisrael
column5: born Teddy T. Thompson and now living in Jacksonville
column6: Fla.
column7: refused for years to give up his old
column8: moldering tapes and carefully selects the memories he shares of the time.

column1: The Numero guys have been through this kind of thing before as they've researched the eight volumes of their Eccentric Soul series
column2: and though technically not part of that series
column3: this could easily have been the ninth volume
column4: between the backstory and the music it contains. The music on the collection was recorded in the early 1980s
column5: as disco faded and rap was on the rise in the nation's biggest city. Continuity wasn't a big thing for Yisrael
column6: and he moved his label from project to project
column7: abandoning previous ones along the way
column8: sometimes without even bothering to release them. Possible deals with the likes of Sugar Hill's Sylvia Robinson fell by the wayside as he set his sites on the next thing
column9: and great early rap tracks that could have blown up if released when they were recorded in 1981 instead fell with a barely audible thump in 1986
column10: years past their shelf date.

column1: Yisrael wasn't running a shoestring operation. He ran the Bronx-based T&T health food chain and was the organizer of the Brotherhood of Wisdom
column2: Temple of Issachar
column3: a storefront church that focused on the Torah. In the past
column4: he'd apprenticed with Motown/Mercury/ OldWorld/Chess/Atco/ producer Gene Redd
column5: Jr.
column6: who ultimately came to work for Tap
column7: and he'd also had a brief acting career
column8: including a role in the 1972 Bond flick Live and Let Die. He poured money into his recording sessions
column9: booking time at Mayfair
column10: Power Station
column11: and Right Track
column12: bringing in string orchestras and professional arrangers
column13: some of whose hand-notated work can be seen in the supplemental book that comes with the CD.

column1: Disco is the bedrock of all of these recordings
column2: and though some manage to be lo-fi in spite of their budgets
column3: they all possess an infectious quality and a stomping
column4: high-tempo groove. Yisrael started with Annette Denvil
column5: who he discovered at a talent show he organized. ""So Nice""
column6: the song included here
column7: features smoothly grooving verses balanced by a somewhat sinister minor-key riff in between. It's good
column8: but it's an hors d'oeuvre relative to what would come after
column9: after Denvil's would-be music career ended with a positive pregnancy test.

column1: The year 1981 held great potential for Tap
column2: as Yisrael latched on to the rap sound that was blowing up in the Bronx and Harlem. He brought in a crew
column3: the Fabulous 3 MCs
column4: and immediately set about finding a female crew to complement them. He turned up Denette ""Missy D"" Scott and charged her with getting a group together. The final Melody Crew included Tanya ""Lady T"" Barns
column5: a member of Kurtis Blow's crew and no small potato in the early rap world. Don't Stop includes one track from each crew
column6: and they're each hugely entertaining slices of live-band disco rap that plays nicely alongside Sugar Hill's early sides. Yisrael attempted to shop Missy Dee's ""Missy Missy Dee""
column7: but never came to satisfactory terms with any prospective label. In the process
column8: he completely neglected the Fabulous 3 MCs
column9: who left bitterly. After a few months of failing to find a home for the Missy Dee track
column10: Yisrael simply moved on
column11: leaving the Melody Crew to break up on its own.

column1: At this point
column2: Redd entered the fold and Yisrael brought on veteran performer Arnie Love
column3: pairing him with two Lovettes for a clutch of fantastic disco-funk tracks. ""Breakout"" has a sick rhythm track
column4: deft arrangement
column5: and outstanding instrumental hook
column6: ""Invisible Wind"" springs from a barreling
column7: horn-laden intro into a sharp if somewhat poorly mixed disco jam
column8: and the other offerings follow in a similar vein. If success was as simple as making a good recording
column9: we'd all know who Arnie Love was
column10: but Jeremiah Yisrael apparently neglected to promote and distribute the handful of Arnie Love 12""s that were produced
column11: though it could have been considered progress that they were pressed at all. Love fell quickly into the rearview mirror as Yisrael threw himself into his next singer
column12: Jackie Stoudemire.

column1: If you know the name
column2: it's because she had a club hit in 1994 with ""Appreciate""
column3: long after her association with Tap ended. During her time with Tap
column4: she never even sniffed a niche chart. She was an associate of Slick Rick and Dana Dane
column5: but Yisrael didn't try her out on any rap songs
column6: instead sticking with the late-period disco he'd recorded with Arnie Love. He even resurrected a few songs from his work with Love
column7: including ""Invisible Wind"". Her version is much slicker and far more chart-ready
column8: but it wasn't to be: Stoudemire had been made to join Yisrael's temple
column9: and clearly wasn't interested in its message of women's subservience to men. Though they continued to record in spite of this
column10: producing the super-smooth choral disco track ""Guilty"" and the funky would-be floor-filler ""Don't Stop Dancin'"".

column1: A few Stoudemire 12""s were pressed
column2: but true to form
column3: flopped spectacularly from a lack of promotion and distribution. Redd became a victim of the AIDS epidemic in 1983
column4: taking his sure hand in the studio with him. Yisrael simply didn't have the skill at a mixing board he needed to continue
column5: and he dismissed Stoudemire. Love was still around but frustrated that he was clearly going nowhere. He ultimately changed his performing name and jumped ship
column6: scoring a very minor hit with a song called ""I'm Out of Your Life"". Yisrael had just a few more trips to the studio in him
column7: for a few ballads and an anti-drug rap song
column8: all deemed unworthy of inclusion here in the liners.

column1: All told
column2: it's kind of remarkable that any good music came out of the Tap story. On paper
column3: it looks like a classic case of ambition exceeding ability
column4: and on the business end it certainly was that. But on the musical end
column5: enough things coalesced just right to create a unique body of work that's only now being properly exposed. Most of the recordings are endearingly rough
column6: and the wild story and generous artwork that accompany it give it a more coherent feel than it had even in real life.

column3: reworked B-Sides

column3: modishly emotional now. More importantly
column4: Dazzle Ships seems a lot less radical than it did on release: The Kraftwerk records and musique concrète it obviously borrowed from have been more fully absorbed into pop music. You'll have heard uglier noises than the title track's mechanical grindings and foghorn blurts

column1: Dazzle Ships was born out of writer's block

column3: or other bassist-free groups
column4: or other bands of literal brothers (frontman Scott and drummer Grant Hutchison are siblings). But somehow
column5: despite the fact that their methods are well-worn
column6: their product is one-of-a-kind
column7: as their consistently great second album (in under a year
column8: no less!) attests.

column1: The key here is Scott's urgent-yet-emotive songwriting. Midnight Organ Flight is full of rousing barnburners that flicker with soul
column2: ballads that ache with masculine vulnerability
column3: and Frightened Rabbit's best song yet
column4: opener ""The Modern Leper"". Built on insistently downstroked guitars and drums that build from a gallop to a thundering crash
column5: this Pixies-go-acoustic track swells with self-loathing. ""Is that you in front of me/ Coming back for even more of exactly the same?/ You must be a masochist/ To love a modern leper on his last leg
column6: sings Scott
column7: and rarely has a song with such anthemic
column8: air-drum-worthy fills been shot through with so much personal revulsion.

column1: Grant's muscular drumming is a highlight throughout the record-- and on stage. At a recent New York show
column2: the band hadn't yet made it through two songs before he'd splintered three drumsticks with his powerful pounding. With the absence of another instrument to hold down the rhythm section (guitarist Billy Kennedy does occasionally fill out the low end with keyboard)
column3: he uses his percussion-- the satisfying hiss of his cymbals
column4: the breathless insistence of his thudding kick drum
column5: the delicious sizzle of his marching-band snare-- to saturate the empty space in the compositions. Flailing about at his kit
column6: he keeps time wildly yet melodically
column7: controlled amidst the chaos.

column1: Despite the trio's static (and relatively spare) set-up
column2: Scott's songs imbue the band with an elastic identity. Scuzzed up tracks like ""Fast Blood"" and almost-bluegrass weepers like ""Good Arms Vs. Bad Arms"" prove that Frightened Rabbit have stretched beyond the melancholic folk-pop of Sing the Greys. But elsewhere-- most notably ""My Backwards Walk"" and ""Old Old Fashioned""-- they re-confirm their dedication to the sound they perfected on their debut
column3: playing electronic and acoustic guitars against each other for stomping mid-tempo gems that pulse with nervous energy and heart-on-sleeve lyrics.

column1: Though nothing else on the album hits the pop high of its opener-- ""Leper"" is a tough act to follow-- its I'm-not-worthy sentiments are prevalent on all the album's best tracks. On ""The Twist""
column2: a desperate yet tender ballad built on a similar freight-train piano line as LCD Soundsystem's ""All My Friends""
column3: the protagonist practically begs for sex-- ""I can be who you like
column4: he pleads-- while sadly allowing himself to be used. ""Whisper the wrong name
column5: sings Scott in his accented bagpipe drone of a voice
column6: ""I don't care and nor do my ears."" In track after track
column7: Scott expresses that need for the warmth of another
column8: however unworthy he may feel of it.

column1: Those sentiments are also echoed in ""Keep Yourself Warm"": ""You won't find love in a hole/ It takes more than fucking someone to keep yourself warm."" He's wallowing
column2: but Scott's cracked voice sells every word
column3: and his band's rousing rhythms and rough-hewn guitar interplay keep the mood from ever getting lugubrious or maudlin. Sure
column4: Frightened Rabbit aren't the first band to explore loneliness
column5: horniness
column6: or emptiness in song
column7: just like they aren't the first set of siblings to decide to jam together
column8: but their jangly melodies claw their way inside your brain just the same
column9: making them latest in a long line of Glasgow bands to effortlessly combine celebratory sonics and miserablist lyrics into something singular.

When you're essentially partners in crime with a band of bad boys like the Black Lips
column2: it takes extra effort not to appear tame by comparison. The Selmanaires have grown up in the burgeoning Atlanta indie scene nearly step-for-step with the Lips
column3: but while both bands brandish a renegade
column4: devil-may-care ethos
column5: they each come at it from very different angles. Playing the ego to the Lips' id
column6: the Selmanaires show off a (slightly) more civilized musicianship
column7: exploring several decades worth of genres versus hedonistically ripping through three-minute Stones and Motown throwbacks.

column1: That's not to say The Air Salesmen doesn't also go down well with a lukewarm can of Milwaukee's Best. On this sophomore effort
column2: the band offers plenty of opportunities for debauchery
column3: though they're cribbed in a more nuanced tone. On one hand
column4: you have a heedless lothario anthem like ""Just to Get Yr Love""
column5: its skyscraping guitar wails and cocksure come-ons a friendly parody of chic retro bands like Wolfmother or the Darkness. That frat-friendly attitude gets turned on its head

column2: Gang of Four

column5: whether in its pleasureless metallic drone or observations on human rationality and determinism. It's no secret ""A Small Room"" and ""GMAFB"" (short for ""Give me a fucking break"") strive to emulate David Byrne's televangelist bark and his band's intricate rhythms
column6: even if the crass demeanor and ham-handed songwriting more closely resemble late-1980s Red Hot Chili Peppers.

column1: While this jerky genre-hopping helps to hold the listener's attention
column2: some dabbling passes by too quickly. The catchy ""Verdigris Intrigue""
column3: for example
column4: is a lone psychedelic daydream amongst rawkers and post-punk reincarnations
column5: a sad fact considering it's the strongest four and a half minutes here. Still
column6: Salesman makes a stronger case for these guys as serious musicians than their clumsier debut
column7: and their enthusiasm
column8: for whichever genre they're copping
column9: remains irrefutable. Even when borrowing from a library of ideas

column11: exceptional bands find a way to make it all sound exclusively their own

Eclecticism is a perennial problem in dance music
column3: indeed one coded into the notion of ""dance music"" itself. Would that be a genre in its own right
column4: or a coalition of separate styles which mix at artists' own risk? The practical grapplers with this issue have tended to be DJs
column5: but in Britain especially there's a tradition of prominent acts who've opted for a ""big-tent"" approach to music-making
column6: cleaving to no particular subgenre and crafting albums which roam freely through clubland and beyond in search of anything that might catch a few ears. 808 State used to do it well
column7: Leftfield proved there was a big market for it
column8: and Basement Jaxx pushed it to a delirious artistic peak.

column1: And Groove Armada? They prove the perils of the big-tent approach. Soundboy Rock is the fifth eclectic album in the duo's eclectic ten-year career
column2: during which they've sold plenty of (highly eclectic) records and the sum total of their pop culture impact has been a car advert about waggling bottoms. And most of the people who rightly hate ""I See You Baby (Shakin That Ass)"" wouldn't even know it was by them.

column1: Thankfully
column2: Soundboy Rock offers two mighty shots at redemption. Messy first single ""Get Down"" is carried by the bubble-and-squeak energy of long-lost grime MC Lady Stush: it's so good to hear her squeal and cackle again that you don't really worry where the hook is. Besides
column3: the glorious follow-up
column4: ""Song 4 Mutya (Out Of Control)""
column5: has all the hook you'll need-- an eighties pop fantasia where New Order collaborate with Prince to soundtrack Mutya Buena's ex-directed anger.

column1: ""Song 4 Mutya"" is inspired
column2: but the rest of Soundboy Rock gives a truer picture of Groove Armada's talents and limitations. Nothing here irritates or even displeases
column3: but almost every track is a stylistic workout missing the killer idea that would make it vital. Candi Staton turns up for a Chicago house tribute
column4: ""Love Sweet Sound""
column5: which gets the style's spacey noises right but not its sensual or spiritual desperation. On the other hand
column6: The Rakes' Alan Donohue MCing about polar bears dying on the indie-dub ""See What You Get"" is a lot less awful than that summary suggests: almost everything on this album tends gently towards the middle.

column1: The group seem happiest here when they're pastiching their own former triumphs. ""From the Rooftops"" and ""Paris"" revisit the group's chill-out roots (and the roots of Chill Out-- both tracks borrow samples from the KLF's seminal album)
column2: swaddling pretty melodies in echo to create a genuinely comfortable comfort zone. ""Lightsonic"" is a cousin of former hit ""Superstylin'""
column3: and the combination of balearic keyboards
column4: big beat and cornball toasting is as stupidly uplifting this time as last.

column1: Groove Armada have touted Soundboy Rock as their best album
column2: and they're probably right
column3: because they've excised the smarmy or irritating elements of their earlier work. The record was inspired by the atmosphere of Lovebox
column4: the London festival they curate and DJ at
column5:
and it certainly proves that they know what great dance music sounds like: it also suggests they lack the spark to consistently make it themselves.
